com.pump.plaf

Class ButtonShape

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pump.plaf.ButtonShape
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    PositionConstants

    public class ButtonShape
extends java.lang.Object
implements PositionConstants
    A mechanism to control the shape of buttons with rounded edges.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ButtonShape

        public ButtonShape(int preferredRadius,
                   int maxRadius)
        Create a new ButtonShape.
        Parameters:
        maxRadius - the max radius for corners. If the corners should always be rounded, then this should be a very large number.
        preferredRadius - the preferred radius for corners. This may define the preferred height of a button.

      • ButtonShape

        public ButtonShape(int prefTopRightRadius,
                   int prefTopLeftRadius,
                   int prefBottomLeftRadius,
                   int prefBottomRightRadius,
                   int maxTopRightRadius,
                   int maxTopLeftRadius,
                   int maxBottomLeftRadius,
                   int maxBottomRightRadius)
        This constructor gives you control over each corner of the button. Most of the time you can probably use the other (simpler) constructor, unless you need this level of control.

    • Method Detail

      • getPreferredSize

        public java.awt.Dimension getPreferredSize(java.awt.Dimension d,
                                           int contentWidth,
                                           int contentHeight,
                                           java.awt.Insets padding,
                                           java.awt.Shape customShape)
        Returns the preferred size of a button should have.
        Parameters:
        d - an optional Dimension to store the results in.
        contentWidth - the width of the innards of this button.
        contentHeight - the height of the innards of this button.
        padding - the padding between the contents and the border.
        customShape - if non-null, then this shape is scaled to fit the rectangle containing the contents and the padding. This is how you apply a custom button shape (like a circle, diamond, arrow, etc.)
        Returns:
        the preferred size of this method.

      • getShape

        public java.awt.geom.GeneralPath getShape(java.awt.geom.GeneralPath path,
                                          int width,
                                          int height)
        Calculates the shape of this button, given certain constraints.
        Parameters:
        path - an optional destination for the outline.
        width - the width to stretch this fill to.
        height - the height to stretch this fill to.

      • getShape

        public java.awt.geom.GeneralPath getShape(java.awt.geom.GeneralPath fillPath,
                                          java.awt.geom.GeneralPath strokePath,
                                          int width,
                                          int height,
                                          int horizontalPosition,
                                          int verticalPosition,
                                          boolean includeStrokePartitions,
                                          java.awt.Shape customShape)
        Calculates the shape of this button, given certain constraints. Note if this is smaller than the preferred size then, well, the results may look bad.
        Parameters:
        fillPath - an optional destination for the button shape.
        strokePath - an optional destination for the border. Often the border and fill will be the same, but in some cases where line segments are meant to be missing: they will be unique.
        width - the width to stretch this fill to.
        height - the height to stretch this fill to.
        horizontalPosition - POS_ONLY, POS_LEFT, POS_RIGHT or POS_MIDDLE
        verticalPosition - POS_ONLY, POS_TOP, POS_BOTTOM or POS_MIDDLE
        customShape - the special shape this button should take. This may be a circle, diamond, arrow, etc.
        Returns:
        the shape of this button, given these constraints.
